channel.title: Comments on: Gmail False Positives Are On The Rise

item.title: By: tester
item.dc:creator: tester
item.description: It seems to be happening again now. I have had about 30 legit emails (from sources that were never marked as spam for the past 3 years) sent to the spam box in the last 2 weeks...
item.content:encoded: It seems to be happening again now. I have had about 30 legit emails (from sources that were never marked as spam for the past 3 years) sent to the spam box in the last 2 weeks…

item.title: By: Ryan
item.dc:creator: Ryan
item.description: I agree. I have found several false positives recently and there appears to be no way to stop or "lower" the SPAM protection, very disappointing.
item.content:encoded: I agree. I have found several false positives recently and there appears to be no way to stop or “lower” the SPAM protection, very disappointing.

item.title: By: v0vets
item.dc:creator: v0vets
item.description: Last 2 weeks I've got a dozen of false positives (good messages in spam box). Some of them were from respectful domains. But I was killed by spam filter today - when me friend (he also uses gmail and we email each other frequently) has received invitation from my googlegroup and it was marked as SPAM !!!!. Impossible. Something should be done - such false positives is a real shame on gmail spam filter.
item.content:encoded:
Last 2 weeks I’ve got a dozen of false positives
(good messages in spam box). Some of them were from respectful
domains.
But I was killed by spam filter today – when me friend (he also uses
gmail and we email each other frequently) has received invitation from
my googlegroup and it was marked as SPAM !!!!.
Impossible.
Something should be done – such false positives is a real shame on
gmail spam filter.

item.title: By: Brian
item.dc:creator: Brian
item.description:
I am wondering if there is a way to say that something is NOT spam. I am getting messages with this in front: "SPAM:: message"
In most cases these messages are NOT spam.
They show up in my inbox, but the subject line has SPAM:: at its onset. If I respond to emails I need to manually change the subject line. I forget sometimes...
Any ideas?
item.content:encoded:
I am wondering if there is a way to say that something is NOT spam. I am getting messages with this in front: “SPAM:: message”

In most cases these messages are NOT spam.

They show up in my inbox, but the subject line has SPAM:: at its onset. If I respond to emails I need to manually change the subject line. I forget sometimes…

Any ideas?

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
@Raanan -
That isn't the case for mine, both direct and forwarded emails are getting caught in the spam folder.
item.content:encoded:
@Raanan –

That isn’t the case for mine, both direct and forwarded emails are getting caught in the spam folder.

item.title: By: Raanan Bar-Cohen
item.dc:creator: Raanan Bar-Cohen
item.description:
I've noticed a similar thing as well lately.
But I do see a trend -- at least in my case. The legit emails getting flagged are all from forwarded accounts, not emails addressed to the gmail address.
item.content:encoded:
I’ve noticed a similar thing as well lately.

But I do see a trend — at least in my case. The legit emails getting flagged are all from forwarded accounts, not emails addressed to the gmail address.

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.content:encoded:
@Jeff –

For as long as I can remember Hotmail has had problems with spam. That was one reason why I never used it much. Having Gmail be better is good, but having false positives is very bad.

@Daniel –

I tried Yahoo’s email service for awhile and really didn’t care for it at all.

@Jim –

I’m trying to incorporate checking my Gmail spam folder once a day into my routine. Hasn’t worked yet, need to leave myself a note some where.

item.title: By: Jim
item.dc:creator: Jim
item.description: After reading your post I went and check my Google junk mail. Sure enough, about half dozen hams in there. :(
item.content:encoded: After reading your post I went and check my Google junk mail. Sure enough, about half dozen hams in there. üôÅ

item.title: By: Daniel Black
item.dc:creator: Daniel Black
item.description: I think this is likely a strategy everyone needs to use, no matter the platform. I've been very careful where I put my GMail address, and use Yahoo! instead as the lowest-common-denominator garbage collector. I've been zero-inboxing Yahoo! for years now, and that includes checking my "Bulk Mail" box daily. I pull a stray false-positive out roughly once a month or so.
item.content:encoded: I think this is likely a strategy everyone needs to use, no matter the platform. I’ve been very careful where I put my GMail address, and use Yahoo! instead as the lowest-common-denominator garbage collector. I’ve been zero-inboxing Yahoo! for years now, and that includes checking my “Bulk Mail” box daily. I pull a stray false-positive out roughly once a month or so.

item.title: By: Jeff Norris
item.dc:creator: Jeff Norris
item.description: Well I wouldn't blame all of it on Google. The craftiness of the spamming community if its really a community changes every day. My GMAIL stays pretty clean compared to hotmail which I have had for 11 years. I think the root of the problem is when WE publish our email address everywhere, so expect the spam crafters to hit us. Frankly google has less false positives that other services I use hotmail, yahoo, aim.com etc. Even fighting my own spam can be a full time gig!
item.content:encoded: Well I wouldn’t blame all of it on Google. The craftiness of the spamming community if its really a community changes every day. My GMAIL stays pretty clean compared to hotmail which I have had for 11 years. I think the root of the problem is when WE publish our email address everywhere, so expect the spam crafters to hit us. Frankly google has less false positives that other services I use hotmail, yahoo, aim.com etc. Even fighting my own spam can be a full time gig!
